Hi <@U07UFF36QEL>,

Seems like you are missing the `<style>` <ALL THE CSS GOES HERE> `</style>` wrap for the CSS, once you add that it should start rendering the CSS styles.

Thanks

• Yes, our subscription types are based on content.
• We have a B2C subscription type and a B2B subscription type.
• In order to send the email, the contacts subscribed to a subscription type have to be on a list. My contacts who are opted into the B2B subscription type are on my B2B subscription list.

In my opinion B2C and B2B shouldn't be a subscription type to choose from because now you have exactly the problem you are facing right now bc you have to sub them both now in order to send them the marketing mail.

B2C/ B2B also shouldn't be a subscription type because its not content.

They are transactions and define a contact like a filter criteria you can't send out B2B because its not content in its own. You can send out a Newsletter thats directed to B2B customers or a newsletter directed to B2C Customers, but they are not itself a content type more a criteria.

Our B2C subscription type is labeled as a "Clinical Newsletter" that focuses on educational content related to their jobs in the medical field.

Our B2B subscription type is labeled as "Business Newsletter" that focuses on management-related content for our contacts that have higher-level positions above clinical staff.

The email that we want to send happens to apply equally to both of these audiences.

Well, I'm not sure how clean it is but you could consider taking each line item on the deal and creating a new child deals from them. Then use same-object association to associate them back to the parent deal. Child deals could go through the same sales process as the parent deal. When all child deals close you could mark the parent as closed.

I suppose you could also create a status and/or date property on line items and do something similar.

I'd like to have a custom field on Deals.

The field would store the data when our product is going live with a customer. This in Year and Quarter format. E.g. Q1,25 Q2,25 Q3,25...etc.

How would you do this? Is there any smarter way than just pushing these values into a dropdown select field and keep that updated by periodically adding new values?

It is very similar to <https://HubSpotdev.slack.com/archives/C011F74BKQW/p1730355667156529|this case> actually, best way is to use the product line items on the deal and each product line item can have a start date.
